metadata.title: Everyone Has an Interview Show, But Nobody Interviews

content.text: Society & Culture Everyone Has an Interview Show, But Nobody Interviews Everyone wants to record themselves chatting. Is that good? Katherine Dee / September 27, 2025 Illustration by Noah Hickey/The Dispatch (Photos via Getty Images). Illustration by Noah Hickey/The Dispatch (Photos via Getty Images). Audio Audio Turn any article into a podcast. Upgre now to start listening. Text Size Facebook Twitter LinkedIn Thres Email 0 Open and scroll to the comments section In Brooklyn apartments, two friends with microphones dissect TikTok trends or recapitulate Twitter drama. There are the marathon sessions like The Joe Rogan Experience, where conversations sprawl like suburban development: three hours of nothing punctuated by moments destined for Instagram Reels. There's the pare of glossy celebrity sit-downs with cinematic camera work that cost thousands to produce, ostensibly have millions of listeners, and yet, you’ve never heard of them. Elsewhere, venture capitalists pontificate about disruption. Influencers dissect relationships with other, slightly better-known influencers. Politicians "reach across the aisle" to controversial public figures, to bond over their shared vocation of being famous. In short, everyone hosts an interview show now. The format takes hold wherever a guest can be found and two voices can fill one to three hours. With a handful of exceptions (Dwarkesh Patel and Ross Douthat both immediately spring to mind, though there are certainly others), preparations for an interview seem to involve no more than sending a calendar invite. Editing means cutting where you accidentally named your situationship. Go deeper down the interview-show rabbit hole and you'll find microphones are optional. There’s zero barrier to entry, infinite upside. Maybe you'll eventually sell out theaters for live recordings. Maybe you'll coast on two hours of work weekly while banking six figures from your Patreon earnings. Maybe you'll become the Joe Rogan of something incredibly specific, like being on your phone all day. Everyone believes they're one viral clip from quitting their day job—and sometimes they're right. Today's carelessness would have horrified early brocasters. Edward R. Murrow’s See It Now in the 1950s set the standard for versarial television journalism and earned national attention when it challenged Sen. Joseph McCarthy. Murrow’s companion program Person to Person, which aired into the early 1960s, by contrast, reached millions of viewers by bringing cameras into public figures’ living rooms, avoiding controversy but establishing the template for the friendlier, intimate interview. Mike Wallace pushed in the other direction: His Night Beat (1956) and The Mike Wallace Interview (1957-58) were so confrontational they were taken off the air as quickly as they appeared. Each show was deliberate—well thought-out—and demanded the viewer’s full attention. That sensibility culminated in 1968 with 60 Minutes, where Wallace turned the interview into a civic ritual with questions framed as public demands for answers. But that era is over; the contemporary interview show does something else entirely. Marathon programs, The Joe Rogan Experience being chief among them, are designed for audiences to drift in and out while they do something else, usually scrolling. Last year I tried to work against this current: With my creative partner, Taylor McMahon, I began an audio documentary about Art Bell, who mainstreamed conspiracy and paranormal talk rio. Every minute demanded dozens of small decisions. My narration h to be written, then re, then re again until I mastered the right cence. What seems effortless when done well depends on time, money, and understanding of a craft that today's shows have largely abandoned, for both good and b reasons. Most interview shows cost nothing to make and less to repeat. They can be monetized through Patreon and Substack, and of course through s. Marketing is embedded in the format: A guest arrives with an audience and lends it to the host for an hour. Hosts accumulate listeners, downlos, and views parasitically, bouncing between audiences to build their own. Clips finish the job. A three-hour conversation becomes a month of 30-second social media reels, which travel further and faster than the original episode ever will. Among creators, produced and edited shows are sometimes dismissed as "sterile," a judgment that confuses careful shaping with absence of life. Listen to episodes of This American Life or Riolab, or The Living Room. This isn’t sterility. They know when to withhold information, when to let silence work. There is a craft to audio. But technique has become suspect—and shows aim to be light and conversational, even ambient. Having craft beyond whatever the algorithm rewards this week makes you seem pretentious, like a “tryhard,” or “striver.” But to the DIY brocaster’s credit, the economics are also brutal: 40 hours of careful editing will likely generate the same number of downlos as two friends recording their hangout. Effort doesn't always scale, unless you’re lucky. The model that taught rio producers timing and pacing—and me them invaluable—is de. The absence of craft has all sorts of consequences. For example, the versarial interview hasn't vanished, but it grows scarcer yearly. Guests arrive with talking points, or even without them, knowing the host won't push back on even the most absurd utterances. Most programs have settled into a therapeutic tempo, where guests say something outrageous and hosts just nod. The performance of conflict persists in some areas because conflict generates effective clips, though it more often manifests as humiliation—gotcha moments rather than genuine hard questioning. In today's media landscape, very few figures still practice real interviewing. Tucker Carlson, paroxically, provides an interesting case study for both real interviews and the sort of galling credulity common to today’s face-to-faces. When Carlson sat down with OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, Carlson actually challenged him, asking Altman about Suchir Balaji, a former OpenAI employee who was found de in an apparent suicide several weeks after accusing OpenAI of copyright violations. Carlson seems to genuinely believe Balaji was murdered—and he pressed Altman on that when Altman said that he believed Balaji h committed suicide. It was a tense back-and-forth. Altman, at one point, tells Carlson he hasn’t done too many interviews where he’s accused of murder. Carlson clarifies—he’s not accusing him of murder, but the situation demands an explanation. By contrast, Carlson’s interview with the writer and podcast Darryl Cooper was exceedingly deferential: When Cooper offered a revisionist picture of the Holocaust, Carlson didn’t question his claims. He accepted them at face value. Less controversially, Ross Douthat also doesn’t sit in the passenger seat. On Interesting Times, he asks guests to explain their positions and actively engages with their arguments. A surprising number of guests fumble when challenged, even lightly. Virtually no one else, however, is conducting interviews with much confrontation. Nobody wants to piss anyone else off. Nobody wants to burn a bridge. The 2024 presidential election was widely considered “the podcast bro” election, and what a missed opportunity it was! Joe Rogan and Theo Von hung out with Trump, Alex Cooper hung out with Kamala Harris on Call Her Ddy. There were no stakes. With presidential nominees! But other podcasts exist less as actual conversations and more as collections of clippable moments. That is, it’s less about the complete product as it is creating raw material for later harvesting, itself designed to help the podcast rack up followers and go viral. This is a culture-wide condition and not confined to podcasting, either. You see this most acutely in the film industry, where many movies seem to exist primarily as fragments for TikTok’s For You page. Sydney Sweeney’s Anyone But You utterly failed the test of narrative craft—really, it was worse than what you’d re in a freshman screenwriting class—but it succeeded brilliantly as a clip generator. There were funny jokes—there was just no plot. To return to podcasting: Call Her Ddy offers a cornucopia of very consumable clips—but as a start-to-finish listening experience, it borders on unbearable. Unless, of course, you’re using it as background noise while you do other things. And it's a pipeline that serves the influencer economy, whether you're a walking lifestyle brand or a public intellectual. Every book demands a tour—and you'll discover, after you've written one, that most interviewers have barely cracked the spine. Or maybe it’s not a book, it’s a new project or a company. The actual content becomes secondary to the fact of its existence. Every tour demands appearances, a circuit of podcasts and shows where you'll repeat the same anecdotes, refine the same talking points, until they calcify. These appearances build familiarity—not with your ideas or your work, but with your face, your voice, your personal “brand.” You become a regular presence in people's feeds. Familiarity breeds recognition, recognition courts fame, and fame confers status and, with any luck, money. What matters is that you're in circulation, generating clips, maintaining visibility. The work, whatever it is, was never the point; it was just your ticket to the circuit. It's fame stripped down to its barest, most cynical mechanics: visibility for visibility's sake. What's the point of this endless circulation? It's no wonder so many would-be internet personalities pivot to politics. At least there, the performance must pretend to be about something real. It’s the last place where you can be famous in a durable way—and not just durable, it means something. You’re less likely to be forgotten with the next news cycle. When television first visited the living room, Murrow's Person to Person gave audiences proximity in exchange for hard questions deferred. Later, 60 Minutes demonstrated that interviews could provide a state for real accountability weekly. Mike Wallace me tobacco executives sweat. Now we have something different: an entire media ecosystem built on circulating one's own image. As the barrier to entry for starting a podcast continues to drop with new tools, craft may become the only remaining competitive vantage—and indeed, exceptional work still breaks through, like Dwarkesh Patel's meticulously-prepared tech and history show. Quality shows remain anomalies in a landscape that mostly tells us our time is worth exactly what the hosts invested. The carefully edited show respects the listener's attention; the unedited conversation treats it as inexhaustible. We live among conversations that never begin and never end, that we enter in progress and leave before completion. Interview shows proliferate—hundreds, thousands—yet most we know only through TikTok soundbites, if we know them at all. Occasionally something remarkable gets said. The rest dissolves. The machine keeps running, always recording, never stopping to ask whether any of this deserves to exist. Katherine Dee Katherine Dee is an internet culture reporter and host of The Computer Room. Her work can be found in UnHerd, Tablet, The Spectator, The Critic, and at her blog, default.blog.

            $nextTick(() => { 
                if (navigator.clipboard && window.isSecureContext) {
                    navigator.clipboard.writeText('https://thedispatch.com/article/interview-show-podcast/');
                } else {
                    // Fallback for non-HTTPS environments
                    const textArea = document.createElement('textarea');
                    textArea.value = 'https://thedispatch.com/article/interview-show-podcast/';
                    document.body.appendChild(textArea);
                    textArea.select();
                    document.execCommand('copy');
                    document.body.removeChild(textArea);
                }
            }); 
            setTimeout(() => { copied = false }, 2000);
        ">

<section :class="{'text-size-sm': ui.textSize === 'sm', 'text-size-lg': ui.textSize === 'lg', 'text-size-xl': ui.textSize === 'xl'}" class="tight-template" id="article-body">
<div class="rich-text core-paragraph">
<p>In Brooklyn apartments, two friends with microphones dissect TikTok trends or recapitulate Twitter drama. There are the marathon sessions like <em>The Joe Rogan Experience</em>, where conversations sprawl like suburban development: three hours of nothing punctuated by moments destined for Instagram Reels. There's the parade of <a href="https://open.spotify.com/show/6UfyXZgVAUX1UzF8j5L72t">glossy celebrity sit-downs</a> with cinematic camera work that cost <a href="https://armchairexpertpod.com/">thousands to produce</a>, ostensibly have millions of listeners, and yet, <a href="https://time.com/collections/100-best-podcasts/7303136/wiser-than-me-with-julia-louis-dreyfus/">you’ve never heard of them</a>. Elsewhere, <a href="https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/invest-like-the-best-with-patrick-oshaughnessy/id1154105909">venture capitalists</a> pontificate about disruption. Influencers dissect relationships with other, <a href="https://www.youtube.com/@prettybasicpodcast">slightly better-known influencers</a>. <a href="https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/this-is-gavin-newsom/id1798358255">Politicians</a> "reach across the aisle" to <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wj09LY67WKU">controversial public figures</a>, to bond over their shared <a href="https://www.youtube.com/@ClubRandomPodcast">vocation of being famous</a>. </p>
</div>
<div class="rich-text core-paragraph">
<p>In short, everyone hosts an interview show now.</p>
</div> <section class="newsletter-paywall-divider piano-container article-paywall piano-block"></section>
<div class="rich-text core-paragraph">
<p>The format takes hold wherever a guest can be found and two voices can fill one to three hours. With a handful of exceptions (<a href="https://www.dwarkesh.com/podcast">Dwarkesh Patel</a> and <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/column/interesting-times">Ross Douthat</a> both immediately spring to mind, though there are certainly others), preparations for an interview seem to involve no more than sending a calendar invite. Editing means cutting where you accidentally named your situationship. Go deeper down the interview-show rabbit hole and you'll find microphones are optional. There’s zero barrier to entry, infinite upside. Maybe you'll eventually sell out theaters for live recordings. Maybe you'll coast on two hours of work weekly while banking six figures from your Patreon earnings. Maybe you'll become the Joe Rogan of something incredibly specific, like being on your phone all day. Everyone believes they're one viral clip from quitting their day job—and sometimes they're right.</p>
</div>
<div class="rich-text core-paragraph">
<p>Today's carelessness would have horrified early broadcasters. Edward R. Murrow’s <em>See It Now</em> in the 1950s set the standard for adversarial television journalism and earned national attention when it <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3aAzb_Esa-E">challenged Sen. Joseph McCarthy</a>. Murrow’s companion program <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7X6ND2U9YeU"><em>Person to Person</em></a>, which aired into the early 1960s, by contrast, reached millions of viewers by bringing cameras into public figures’ living rooms, avoiding controversy but establishing the template for the friendlier, intimate interview. Mike Wallace pushed in the other direction: His <em>Night Beat</em> (1956) and <em>The Mike Wallace Interview</em> (1957-58) were so confrontational they were taken off the air as quickly as they appeared. Each show was deliberate—well thought-out—and demanded the viewer’s full attention. That sensibility culminated in 1968 with <em>60 Minutes</em>, where Wallace turned the interview into a civic ritual with questions framed as public demands for answers. </p>
</div>
<div class="rich-text core-paragraph">
<p>But that era is over; the contemporary interview show does something else entirely. Marathon programs, <em>The</em> <em>Joe Rogan Experience</em> being chief among them, are designed for audiences to drift in and out while they do something else, usually scrolling. Last year I tried to work against this current: With my creative partner, Taylor McMahon, I began an <a href="https://default.blog/p/first-time-caller-an-art-bell-tribute">audio documentary</a> about <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HazoA8hJ-oc">Art Bell</a>, who mainstreamed conspiracy and paranormal talk radio. Every minute demanded dozens of small decisions. My narration had to be written, then read, then read again until I mastered the right cadence. What seems effortless when done well depends on time, money, and understanding of a craft that today's shows have largely abandoned, for both good and bad reasons.</p>
</div>
<div class="rich-text core-paragraph">
<p>Most interview shows cost nothing to make and less to repeat. They can be monetized through Patreon and Substack, and of course through ads. Marketing is embedded in the format: A guest arrives with an audience and lends it to the host for an hour. Hosts accumulate listeners, downloads, and views parasitically, bouncing between audiences to build their own. Clips finish the job. A three-hour conversation becomes a month of 30-second social media reels, which travel further and faster than the original episode ever will.</p>
</div>
<div class="rich-text core-paragraph">
<p>Among creators, produced and edited shows are sometimes dismissed as "sterile," a judgment that confuses careful shaping with absence of life. Listen to episodes of <em>This American Life</em> or <em>Radiolab</em>, or <em>The Living Room</em>. This isn’t sterility. They know when to withhold information, when to let silence work. There is a <em>craft</em> to audio. But technique has become suspect—and shows aim to be light and conversational, even ambient.   </p>
</div>
<div class="rich-text core-paragraph">
<p>Having craft beyond whatever the algorithm rewards this week makes you seem pretentious, like a “tryhard,” or “striver.” But to the DIY broadcaster’s credit, the economics are also brutal: 40 hours of careful editing will likely generate the same number of downloads as two friends recording their hangout. Effort doesn't always scale, unless you’re lucky. The model that taught radio producers timing and pacing—and made them invaluable—is dead. </p>
</div>
<div class="rich-text core-paragraph">
<p>The absence of craft has all sorts of consequences. For example, the adversarial interview hasn't vanished, but it grows scarcer yearly. Guests arrive with talking points, or even without them, knowing the host won't push back on even the most absurd utterances. Most programs have settled into a therapeutic tempo, where guests say something outrageous and hosts just nod. The performance of conflict persists in some areas because conflict generates effective clips, though it more often manifests <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7jJMxXsaKNI">as humiliation</a>—gotcha moments rather than genuine hard questioning. </p>
</div>
<div class="rich-text core-paragraph">
<p>In today's media landscape, very few figures still practice real interviewing. Tucker Carlson, paradoxically, provides an interesting case study for both real interviews and the sort of galling credulity common to today’s face-to-faces. </p>
</div>
<div class="rich-text core-paragraph">
<p>When Carlson sat down with OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, Carlson actually challenged him, <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5KmpT-BoVf4">asking Altman</a> about Suchir Balaji, a former OpenAI employee who was found dead in an apparent suicide several weeks after accusing OpenAI of copyright violations. Carlson seems to genuinely believe Balaji was murdered—and he pressed Altman on that when Altman said that he believed Balaji had committed suicide. It was a tense back-and-forth. Altman, at one point, tells Carlson he hasn’t done too many interviews where he’s accused of murder. Carlson clarifies—he’s not accusing him of murder, but the situation demands an explanation. </p>
</div>
<div class="rich-text core-paragraph">
<p>By contrast, Carlson’s interview with the writer and podcast Darryl Cooper was exceedingly deferential: When Cooper offered a revisionist picture of the Holocaust, Carlson didn’t question his claims. He accepted them at face value.  </p>
</div>
<div class="rich-text core-paragraph">
<p>Less controversially, Ross Douthat also doesn’t sit in the passenger seat. On <em>Interesting Times</em>, he asks guests to <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YAJMnZ8QkmY">explain their positions</a> and <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vV7YgnPUxcU">actively engages with their arguments</a>. A surprising number of guests fumble when challenged, even lightly.</p>
</div>
<div class="rich-text core-paragraph">
<p>Virtually no one else, however, is conducting interviews with much confrontation. Nobody wants to piss anyone else off. Nobody wants to burn a bridge. The 2024 presidential election was widely considered “the podcast bro” election, and what a missed opportunity it was! <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hBMoPUAeLnY">Joe Rogan</a> and <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vC5cHjcgt5g">Theo Von</a> <em>hung out</em> with Trump, Alex Cooper <em>hung out</em> with Kamala Harris on <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wFsFl8L7BT0"><em>Call Her Daddy</em></a>. There were no stakes. With presidential nominees! </p>
</div>
<div class="rich-text core-paragraph">
<p>But other podcasts exist less as actual conversations and more as collections of clippable moments. That is, it’s less about the complete product as it is creating raw material for later harvesting, itself designed to help the podcast rack up followers and go viral. This is a culture-wide condition and not confined to podcasting, either. You see this most acutely in the film industry, where many movies seem to exist primarily as fragments for TikTok’s For You page. Sydney Sweeney’s <em>Anyone But You</em> utterly failed the test of narrative craft—really, it was worse than what you’d read in a freshman screenwriting class—but it succeeded brilliantly as a clip generator. There <em>were</em> funny jokes—there was just no plot. To return to podcasting: <em>Call Her Daddy</em> offers a cornucopia of very <a href="https://www.youtube.com/shorts/f54iOzO8ol0">consumable clips</a>—but as a start-to-finish listening experience, it borders on <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kzLrHTEvVfE">unbearable</a>. Unless, of course, you’re using it as background noise while you do other things. </p>
</div>
<div class="rich-text core-paragraph">
<p>And it's a pipeline that serves the influencer economy, whether you're a walking lifestyle brand or a public intellectual. Every book demands a tour—and you'll discover, after you've written one, that most interviewers have barely cracked the spine. Or maybe it’s not a book, it’s a new project or a company. The actual content becomes secondary to the fact of its existence. Every tour demands appearances, a circuit of podcasts and shows where you'll repeat the same anecdotes, refine the same talking points, until they calcify. These appearances build familiarity—not with your ideas or your work, but with your face, your voice, your personal “brand.” You become a regular presence in people's feeds. Familiarity breeds recognition, recognition courts fame, and fame confers status and, with any luck, money. </p>
</div>
<div class="rich-text core-paragraph">
<p>What matters is that you're in circulation, generating clips, maintaining visibility. The work, whatever it is, was never the point; it was just your ticket to the circuit. It's fame stripped down to its barest, most cynical mechanics: visibility for visibility's sake. What's the point of this endless circulation? It's no wonder so many would-be internet personalities pivot to politics. At least there, the performance must pretend to be about something real. It’s the last place where you can be famous in a durable way—and not just durable, it <em>means</em> something. You’re less likely to be forgotten with the next news cycle. </p>
</div>
<div class="rich-text core-paragraph">
<p>When television first visited the living room, Murrow's <em>Person to Person</em> gave audiences proximity in exchange for hard questions deferred. Later, <em>60 Minutes</em> demonstrated that interviews could provide a state for real accountability weekly. Mike Wallace made <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1_-Vu8LrUDk">tobacco executives sweat</a>. Now we have something different: an entire media ecosystem built on circulating one's own image.</p>
</div>
<div class="rich-text core-paragraph">
<p>As the barrier to entry for starting a podcast continues to drop with new tools, craft may become the only remaining competitive advantage—and indeed, exceptional work still breaks through, like Dwarkesh Patel's <a href="https://time.com/7012877/dwarkesh-patel/">meticulously-prepared tech and history show</a>. Quality shows remain anomalies in a landscape that mostly tells us our time is worth exactly what the hosts invested. The carefully edited show respects the listener's attention; the unedited conversation treats it as inexhaustible.</p>
</div>
<div class="rich-text core-paragraph">
<p>We live among conversations that never begin and never end, that we enter in progress and leave before completion. Interview shows proliferate—hundreds, thousands—yet most we know only through TikTok soundbites, if we know them at all. Occasionally something remarkable gets said. The rest dissolves. The machine keeps running, always recording, never stopping to ask whether any of this deserves to exist.</p>
</div></section>

<script>
    tp = window["tp"] || [];
    tp.push(["init", () => {
        let tags_to_push = [];

        let paywall_level =  "metered";
        let post_tags =  ["movies","media","television","social-media","tucker-carlson","opinion","media-criticism","internet-culture"];
        let date_published =  1758941100;
        let authors =  ["Katherine Dee"];
        let category =  ["culture"];
        let newsletter_brand =  "";
        let podcast_brand =  "";
        let post_type =  "post-type-post";
        let debate_series =  "";

        if (paywall_level) {
            tags_to_push.push(paywall_level);
        }

        if (post_tags) {
            post_tags.forEach(tag => {
                tags_to_push.push(tag);
            });
            if (post_type) {
                tags_to_push.push(post_type);
            }
        }

        if (newsletter_brand) {
            tags_to_push.push(newsletter_brand);
        }

        if (podcast_brand) {
            tags_to_push.push(podcast_brand);
        }

        if (debate_series) {
            tags_to_push.push(debate_series);
        }

        if (tags_to_push.length > 0) {
            // The content tags
            tp.push(["setTags", tags_to_push]);
        }

        if (category) {
            // The content section
            tp.push(["setContentSection", category[0]]);
        }

        if (authors) {
            // The content author(s)
            tp.push(["setContentAuthor", authors]);
        }

        if (date_published) {
            /* Currently date_published is epoch time in seconds 
                The publish date should be an ISO 8601-formatted string that includes the published date and time of the content, 
                local to your website's timezone. For instance, a piece of content that was published at 4am in New York on April 3rd, 2017 
                would be set like this:
                tp.push(["setContentCreated", "2017-04-03T08:00:00"]);
                tp.push(["setContentCreated", "2017-04-03T04:00:00-04:00"]);
            */
            let date_published_formatted = new Date(date_published * 1000).toISOString();
            // The content published date
            tp.push(["setContentCreated", date_published_formatted]);
        }
    }]);
</script>
</div>

<div :aria-hidden="!ui.menuOpen" aria-label="Main navigation menu" class="hidden lg:flex fixed top-0 bottom-0 left-0 z-desktop-menu" role="dialog" x-cloak="" x-data="{ 
        newsletterShelfOpened: false,
        activeShelf: null,
        focusedShelfItem: 0,
        mouseInMenu: false,
        mouseInShelf: false,
        openShelf(shelf, focusFirst = false) {
            this.activeShelf = shelf;
            if (shelf === 'newsletters') {
                this.newsletterShelfOpened = true;
                if (this.user.valid) {
                    this.getIterableUser();
                }
            }
            this.focusedShelfItem = 0;
            // Focus first item in shelf for keyboard navigation
            if (focusFirst || !this.mouseInMenu) {
                this.$nextTick(() => {
                    const firstLink = this.$refs[shelf + 'Shelf']?.querySelector('a, button');
                    if (firstLink) firstLink.focus();
                });
            }
        },
        closeShelf() {
            // Only close if mouse is not in menu or shelf
            if (!this.mouseInMenu && !this.mouseInShelf) {
                this.activeShelf = null;
                this.focusedShelfItem = 0;
            }
        },
        handleMainMenuKeydown(event) {
            const menuContainer = event.currentTarget;
            const items = Array.from(menuContainer.querySelectorAll('a, button')).filter(el => 
                !el.closest('[x-show]') || el.closest('[x-show]').style.display !== 'none'
            );
            const currentIndex = items.indexOf(document.activeElement);
            
            switch(event.key) {
                case 'ArrowDown':
                    event.preventDefault();
                    const nextIndex = currentIndex === -1 ? 0 : Math.min(currentIndex + 1, items.length - 1);
                    items[nextIndex]?.focus();
                    break;
                case 'ArrowUp':
                    event.preventDefault();
                    const prevIndex = currentIndex === -1 ? items.length - 1 : Math.max(currentIndex - 1, 0);
                    items[prevIndex]?.focus();
                    break;
                case 'ArrowRight':
                    // If focused element has a shelf, open it
                    const focusedElement = document.activeElement;
                    if (focusedElement?.hasAttribute('x-ref')) {
                        const ref = focusedElement.getAttribute('x-ref');
                        const shelfName = ref?.replace('Trigger', '');
                        if (shelfName && this.$refs[shelfName + 'Shelf']) {
                            event.preventDefault();
                            this.openShelf(shelfName, true); // Pass true to focus first item
                        }
                    }
                    break;
            }
        },
        handleShelfKeydown(event, shelf) {
            const items = Array.from(this.$refs[shelf + 'Shelf'].querySelectorAll('a, button'));
            const currentIndex = items.indexOf(document.activeElement);
            
            switch(event.key) {
                case 'ArrowDown':
                    event.preventDefault();
                    const nextIndex = Math.min(currentIndex + 1, items.length - 1);
                    items[nextIndex]?.focus();
                    break;
                case 'ArrowUp':
                    event.preventDefault();
                    const prevIndex = Math.max(currentIndex - 1, 0);
                    items[prevIndex]?.focus();
                    break;
                case 'ArrowLeft':
                    event.preventDefault();
                    this.activeShelf = null;
                    // Return focus to the trigger button
                    this.$refs[shelf + 'Trigger']?.focus();
                    break;
            }
        },
        handleNonShelfHover() {
            // Close shelf when hovering non-shelf sections
            if (!this.mouseInShelf) {
                this.activeShelf = null;
            }
        }
    }" x-on:keydown.esc="ui.menuOpen=false; activeShelf=null" x-show="ui.menuOpen" x-trap.noscroll="ui.menuOpen">
<div @keydown="handleMainMenuKeydown($event)" @mouseenter="mouseInMenu = true" @mouseleave="mouseInMenu = false; setTimeout(() => closeShelf(), 100)" class="h-screen overflow-y-auto bg-white w-[325px] relative z-20" x-transition:enter="transition-all duration-300 ease-in-out" x-transition:enter-end="translate-x-0" x-transition:enter-start="-translate-x-full" x-transition:leave="transition-all duration-300 ease-in-out" x-transition:leave-end="-translate-x-full" x-transition:leave-start="translate-x-0">
<div class="px-8 py-6">
